Article Title: US markets today: Wall Street slips as Nvidia extends losing streak; global tech rout deepens after Cloudflare glitch
Article Text: Wall Street lost ground again on Tuesday as a fresh slide in Nvidia and other major technology stocks weighed on sentiment, adding to concerns that recent valuations had climbed too high. Early trading saw the S&P 500 fall 0.3%, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 361 points and the Nasdaq composite declining 0.6%, AP reported.The weakness followed another volatile stretch for the US market. Home Depot was among the biggest drags after reporting summer-quarter profit below expectations, with the retailer attributing the shortfall to fewer major storms, anxious consumers and a continuing slowdown in the housing market. The company’s shares fell 3.1% and it cut its fiscal 2025 adjusted earnings guidance while raising its sales growth outlook.The rout in artificial-intelligence-related stocks continued to shape market direction. Nvidia, whose shares have fallen 8.6% this month, slipped another 1.1% ahead of its earnings announcement due on Wednesday after a 1.9% decline on Monday. Other chipmakers—including Micron, Intel and Qualcomm—lost between 1% and 2%.Among the tech giants, Microsoft slid 1.5% while Amazon dropped 1.8%.Cloudflare shares also weakened after a technical issue at the internet infrastructure provider triggered global outages affecting services such as ChatGPT. European and Asian markets followed Wall Street lower, with major indices in Germany, France and the UK down 1.4% by midday.Futures trading mirrored the cautious mood, with S&P 500 and Dow futures down 0.6% and 0.7% respectively, and Nasdaq futures retreating 0.7%.Investors are also bracing for the delayed US employment data, scheduled for release on Thursday after the prolonged government shutdown. The update is expected to influence the US Federal Reserve’s next interest rate move. While markets had anticipated continued rate cuts to support a weakening labour market, officials have pointed to the risk of worsening inflation, which remains above the 2% target.A strong jobs report could delay further rate cuts, while particularly weak numbers may raise concerns about economic momentum. Fed policymakers have also cited limited data availability due to the shutdown as a reason for adopting a more cautious stance.Across Asia, markets retreated sharply. Japan’s 30-year government bond yield surged to 3.31% as Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi prepared higher government spending plans and delayed efforts to reduce public debt. The yen hovered above 155 per dollar. The Nikkei 225 slumped 3.2%, dragged down by major chip-related names including Tokyo Electron, which fell 5.5%, and Advantest, down 3.7%.In Seoul, the Kospi tumbled 3.3%, with Samsung Electronics losing 2.8% and SK Hynix sinking 5.9%. Taiwan’s Taiex fell 2.5% as TSMC retreated 2.8%. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng index dropped 1.7%, while China’s Shanghai Composite lost 0.8%. Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 shed 1.9%.Other high-momentum assets also softened. Bitcoin extended recent declines, slipping another 1% to around $91,360, its lowest level since April. Gold eased slightly to $4,039 an ounce.In the energy market, US benchmark crude held steady just under $60 a barrel.
Article Summary: S&P 500 falls 0.3%, with Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 361 points. Home Depot among biggest drags after reporting summer-quarter profit below expectations. European and Asian markets follow Wall Street lower, with major indices in Germany, France and the UK down 1.4% by midday.

Article Title: US jobs & AI: Donald Trump adviser blames AI-led efficiency for labour market 'quiet time'; views hiring slowdown as temporary
Article Text:
File photo: Senior Trump administration economic adviser Kevin Hassett (Picture credit: AP)

AI’s impact on hiring and productivity

Trump administration’s stance and recent AI debate

Affordability concerns and grocery price debate

Artificial intelligence could be boosting worker productivity to a level where companies feel less pressure to hire, senior Trump administration economic adviser Kevin Hassett said on Monday.Speaking on CNBC’s Squawk Box, the National Economic Council director said he has noticed “mixed signals in the job market” but “really, really positive signals in the output markets,” as per CNBC.Hassett pointed to strong US GDP growth in the second quarter of 2025 and suggested that firms may be experiencing a “quiet time in the labour market” because AI is making staff significantly more efficient.According to CNBC, he said companies may feel they “don’t necessarily have to hire the new kids out of college and so on.”However, Hassett stressed that any AI-driven cooling in the job market would likely be short-lived.He explained that rapid output and income growth would allow the free market to “work out” these imbalances as new spending avenues emerge.While concerns about AI replacing entry-level roles are not new, they are rarely voiced by the Trump administration, which has strongly promoted the technology, reported CNBC.President Donald Trump has issued several executive orders aimed at reducing regulatory hurdles and expanding AI infrastructure such as data centres.Earlier this month, Trump’s AI and cryptocurrency “czar” David Sacks said there would be “no federal bailout for AI.”His comment followed OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar’s call for a federal “backstop” to support infrastructure investments, which she later walked back, reported CNBC.Hassett’s remarks also come as Trump and his allies try to shift attention to affordability after Democrats gained ground by focusing on cost-of-living issues, according to CNBC.He acknowledged that grocery prices have not fallen during Trump’s second term, despite the president’s claims. Hassett said Americans are still “trying to dig out from the big hole that was dug by the previous administration’s policies,” though he argued that prices have “gone up almost not at all” since Trump returned to office and that “purchasing power has gone up.”
Article Summary: National Economic Council director Kevin Hassett spoke on CNBC's Squawk Box. He suggested firms may be experiencing a ‘quiet time in the labour market’ Hassett stressed that any AI-driven cooling in the job market would likely be short- lived.

Article Title: Explained: Why Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway is betting on Google-parent Alphabet? All you need to know
Article Text:
File photo: Warren Buffett (Picture credit: AP)

What exactly did Berkshire buy?



Why is this investment important?

Who actually made the call—Buffett or his deputies?

What else was happening in Berkshire’s portfolio?

What does this mean going forward?

Alphabet’s shares climbed sharply this week after Warren Buffett ’s Berkshire Hathaway revealed a multibillion-dollar investment in the Google parent.The move is significant because Buffett has rarely backed fast-growing tech firms. Filings showed Alphabet is now one of Berkshire’s top ten holdings.A quarterly 13F filing showed Berkshire held around $4.3 billion worth of Alphabet shares as of 30 September.According to CNBC, this makes Alphabet the conglomerate’s 10th-largest holding.Berkshire purchased 17.85 million shares, valued at $4.93 billion based on last Friday’s close.Buffett has been cautious about traditional tech stocks for decades.As per CNBC, he only viewed Apple—Berkshire’s largest investment—as a consumer-products company rather than a tech business. This makes the Alphabet purchase unusual and closely watched.Alphabet is the best-performing “Magnificent Seven” stock this year, up 46%, according to Reuters.Even with those gains, it trades at a lower valuation than Microsoft, Nvidia or Broadcom, which may have appealed to Berkshire.While Buffett approves major decisions, CNBC reported that the Alphabet move likely came from portfolio managers Todd Combs or Ted Weschler.They have been behind several earlier tech-leaning investments, including Amazon in 2019.Both influence growing parts of Berkshire’s $300 billion equity portfolio.Why does Alphabet fit Berkshire’s value approach?Analyst quoted by CNBC said that Alphabet’s strong cash flows, dominant market position and more modest valuation compared to other AI-driven companies made it attractive.Google Cloud has also shifted from a loss-making unit to a key profit contributor. CFRA analyst Angelo Zino said Alphabet offers “high free cash flow potential” at a valuation Berkshire may find comfortable.According to Reuters, Berkshire trimmed its stakes in Apple and Bank of America during the same quarter. Its cash reserves hit a record $381.7 billion, showing Buffett’s cautious view on expensive markets.Against that backdrop, Alphabet appears to be one of the few large investments Buffett’s team was willing to make.Analysts quoted by Reuters said the Alphabet purchase aligns more closely with Berkshire’s traditional value-driven strategy than other AI-led tech stocks.The deal also comes as Buffett prepares to hand leadership to Greg Abel at the end of 2025, making it likely one of the final major portfolio moves under his tenure.Alphabet’s strong position in AI, its large advertising revenue base and its expanding cloud business appear to have given Berkshire enough confidence to make a rare big bet in the technology sector.
Article Summary: Berkshire Hathaway revealed a multibillion-dollar investment in the Google parent. The move is significant because Buffett has rarely backed fast-growing tech firms. Filings showed Alphabet is now one of Berkshire’s top ten holdings.

Article Title: Busting myths! H-1B visa holders are not ‘cheap labour’
Article Text:
H-1B visas are important: they are the route to getting highly skilled foreign nationals to work in the US. (AI image)

Big Relief For Indians: Donald Trump Clarifies $100K H-1B Fee Won’t Apply To Existing Visa Holders

Why are H-1B visas important?



Who benefits from H-1B visas in the US?

Approved H-1B petitions and denial rates for initial employment

Approved H-1B petitions and denial rates for continuing employment

Do H-1B visa restrictions really help the US? No!

Denial rate for H-1B petitions

H-1B visas, on which the Donald Trump administration is imposing increasing restrictions, are actually beneficial for the US economy and unlike some people who claim that they constitute ‘cheap labour’, evidence seems to suggest otherwise, says National Foundation for American Policy (NFAP) in its latest report.US President Donald Trump had in September announced a $100,000 fee for fresh H-1B visa applicants, a move that has added growing uncertainty to the employment prospects of several foreign nationals, including Indians, who wish to work in America. The Trump administration is also mulling a new wage-weighted system as selection criterion for H-1B visas, doing away with the current lottery-based system.The US Citizenship and Immigration Services has released guidance confirming that the $100,000 fee would be levied only on new H-1B visa holders coming into US and not people change from one visa category to another without leaving the United States; for example it would not be applicable if an individual moves from F-1 student status to H-1B status.A proposed rule by the Trump government, published in September 2025 would disadvantage international students in the H-1B lottery selection, NFAP says, arguing that increasing restrictions may be counter-productive. But first let’s understand why H-1B visas are important:H-1B visas are important: they are the route to getting highly skilled foreign nationals to work in the US. They serve as the main pathway for these foreign nationals, including international students, to get long-term employment in America, build their careers and potentially obtain permanent residency and citizenship in the US.The pool from which employers select highly skilled professionals with recent advanced degrees in key technical fields is composed largely of foreign nationals, says NFAP.Statistics quoted in the NFAP report show that international students actually constituted a huge 71% of full-time graduate enrolment in computer and information sciences programmes and 73% in electrical and computer engineering courses at US universities!USCIS data indicates that nearly two-thirds of recent H-1B visa holders have master's degrees or higher qualifications. Without the H-1B visa status, foreign nationals often must relocate to countries like China, India, Canada or other nations, the report says. The NFAP analysis indicates approximately 700,000 individuals currently reside and work in the United States under H-1B status.Importantly, critics of the H-1B visa system and proponents of increasing curbs on employing foreign nationals in the US argue that it is majorly ‘outsourcing’ firms that draw the maximum benefits from this category of visas. However the FY 2025 numbers present a completely different picture!In fiscal year 2025, Amazon bagged the highest number (4,644) of approved H-1B petitions for initial employment, whilst Meta Platforms, Microsoft and Google followed with 1,555, 1,394 and 1,050 approvals respectively, as per NFAP's examination of USCIS records. H-1B petitions for initial employment are primarily for new employment.This is actually the first time when these four big American technology firms have dominated the top positions for new H-1B petition approvals. According to NFAP, the recruitment activities are on the back of $380 billion investment in AI and associated capital expenditure in 2025.A notable trend has emerged: only three India-based firms appeared amongst the top 25 employers for initial employment H-1B petition approvals in FY 2025. The seven leading India-based companies secured only 4,573 initial employment H-1B approvals in FY 2025, showing a 70% reduction from FY 2015 and 37% decrease from FY 2024.Regarding continuing employment H-1B petitions in FY 2025, Amazon led with 14,532 approvals, followed by TCS (5,293), Microsoft (4,863), Meta Platforms (4,740), Apple (4,610) and Google (4,509). These figures do not correspond to individual employees, as H-1B holders may receive multiple continuing employment approvals within a year due to location changes. Combining initial and continuing employment figures for employers presents an inaccurate representation, says NFAP.Given the FY 2025 H-1B numbers, H-1B critics will likely need a new argument, says NFAP.NFAP is of the view that the fundamental issue with the H-1B category of US visas lies not in its organisation-wse distribution, but rather in its restrictive annual cap of 85,000! This cap is just 0.05% of the American workforce! This limit has consistently proved insufficient for over 20 years, NFAP says.NFAP points out that Trump’s first-term policies seem to be shaping the ongoing move for enhanced restrictions for foreign nationals working in the US. This could lead to higher denial rates for H-1B visas, causing challenges for businesses, cautions NFAP.According to USCIS data, H-1B professionals in computer-related roles earned an average yearly salary of $136,000 and a median of $125,000 in FY 2024, contradicting assertions that these workers constitute ‘cheap labour’.“Some policymakers who favor restrictive immigration policies have argued that foreign-born scientists and engineers may be “cheap labor.” However, the average annual salary for an H-1B visa holder in computer-related occupations in FY 2024 was $136,000, and the median salary was $125,000, according to USCIS statistics,” it says.The USCIS data show H-1B visa holders are paid high salaries, and it contradicts the idea that these are low-skilled people since employers would not pay people with low skills such high salaries,” says Mark Regets, economist at NFAP.Data and economics indicate it is a mistake to assume a fixed number of jobs and that foreign-born scientists and engineers prevent US engineers and computer specialists from gaining jobs.“The number of US-born workers employed in computer science and mathematical occupations increased by over 2.7 million, or 141%, between 2003 and 2024,” according to a National Foundation for American Policy analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics data quoted by NFAP.Industry experts have emphasised that IT service providers that utilise H-1B visas actually contribute positively to US companies and consumers through enhanced productivity and competitiveness.NFAP notes that there is a valid reason why US companies are willing to pay such large sums for acquiring talent through H-1B visas - “The services provided, particularly by more established companies, are specialized and often involve substantial project-oriented contracts for several hundred million dollars or even $1 billion to provide technical skills, services or knowledge that US companies do not possess in-house or that do not make sense to staff in-house,” says NFAP.In a May 2020 study by the National Foundation for American Policy, economist Madeline Zavodny concluded, "H-1B visa holders do not adversely affect US workers. On the contrary, the evidence points to the presence of H-1B visa holders being associated with lower unemployment rates and faster earnings growth among college graduates, including recent college graduates."Limiting H-1B visas appears to push employment and innovation beyond US borders. "[A]ny policies that are motivated by concerns about the loss of native jobs should consider that policies aimed at reducing immigration have the unintended consequence of encouraging firms to offshore jobs abroad," says research by Britta Glennon, an assistant professor at the Wharton School of Business at UPENN."When US firms are denied H-1Bs, they go abroad, setting up new foreign affiliates and hiring talent there instead of in the US," Glennon notes. "For the most global multinational companies, this is at almost a 1:1 rate. The results demonstrate an important unintended consequence of immigration restrictions: the movement of jobs and talent abroad, with major implications for US competitiveness."Research by economist Giovanni Peri and colleagues indicates that the current low H-1B caps prevent firms from generating hundreds of thousands of positions for US workers by limiting business expansion and other opportunities.“Policies toward high-skilled foreign nationals in America remain more restrictive than those of other countries that the United States competes with for talent. The Trump administration is making US immigration policies more restrictive by implementing measures that officials proposed or enacted during Donald Trump’s first term. The policies could lead to fewer international students attending US universities and more companies sending work and resources outside the United States,” NFAP says.Though Donald Trump seems to have taken a U-turn a few days ago, contending that US needs 'certain talent', it remains to be seen whether the stance on H-1B visa restrictions will change.
Article Summary: US President Donald Trump had in September announced a $100,000 fee for fresh H-1B visa applicants. The move that has added growing uncertainty to the employment prospects of several foreign nationals, including Indians, who wish to work in America. The Trump administration is also mulling a new wage-weighted system as selection criterion.

Article Title: Market watch: Asian stocks slip as investors await key US data; crude edges lower on easing supply worries
Article Text:
File photo (Picture credit: AP)

Asian markets fell on Tuesday as caution spread across global equities ahead of several delayed US economic releases and shifting expectations around the Federal Reserve’s next move.The weakness followed a tech-led slide on Wall Street overnight, with investors watching closely for Thursday’s September nonfarm payrolls report to gauge the strength of the US economy.Stocks across the region opened lower. As per news agency Reuters, MSCI’s broad Asia-Pacific index excluding Japan was down 0.7%, while Japan’s Nikkei tumbled more than 2%.The Topix slipped 0.6%, South Korea’s Kospi dropped 0.64% and the Kosdaq 0.58%. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng index declined 0.86%, and Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 lost 0.76%. Mainland China’s CSI 300 traded flat.Sentiment in Japan was also shaped by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s first meeting with Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda since taking office, as per Reuters.Analysts at JBWere said markets were keen to see how the new leadership would balance easy-policy preferences with Ueda’s recent signals of a possible rate hike as early as next month.Takaichi and finance minister Satsuki Katayama have publicly backed keeping rates low until inflation stays near the BOJ’s 2% target.As per CNBC, Bond yields in Japan continued to climb, with the 20-year yield rising to 2.78%—its highest since 1999—while the 10-year yield hit 1.751%.Overnight in the US, the Dow lost 557 points, or 1.18%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.92% and 0.84%.Nvidia slipped nearly 2% ahead of its earnings due Wednesday, dragging other tech shares lower amid growing concerns about stretched valuations.Investors have dialled back expectations of a Fed rate cut in December, as per Reuters, with markets now pricing in roughly a 40% chance, down from over 60% earlier this month.The cautious mood kept the dollar index 0.2% higher at 99.545, while the yen weakened to 155.29 per dollar, its softest since early February. Japan’s finance minister said she was “alarmed” by the currency’s recent volatility, reported Reuters.Commodities also reflected the risk-off tone. Gold slipped 0.3% to $4,030 an ounce, while Brent crude fell nearly 0.5% to $63.91 a barrel.Oil prices softened further after Russia’s Novorossiysk port resumed loadings sooner than expected following a two-day halt caused by a Ukrainian drone and missile strike.Brent dipped 28 cents to $63.92 and US WTI eased 26 cents to $59.65.IG analyst Tony Sycamore said crude was trading slightly lower as operations normalised.Exports from Novorossiysk and the nearby CPC terminal—together responsible for about 2% of global supply—had been paused late last week, briefly lifting prices more than 2%.Traders are now watching the longer-term impact of Western sanctions on Russian flows, with the US treasury noting that restrictions on Rosneft and Lukoil were already squeezing Moscow’s revenues.A senior White House official quoted by Reuters said that President Donald Trump is prepared to sign sanctions legislation as long as final control stays with him. Trump also said Republicans were working on a bill that could target any country doing business with Russia, potentially including Iran.Goldman Sachs expects oil prices to decline through 2026 due to a wave of new supply, though it noted Brent could climb above $70 in 2026-27 if Russian output drops sharply, reported Reuters. Bitcoin edged up 0.3% after touching a seven-month low earlier in the session, with nearly 22% wiped off its value in three months.
Article Summary: MSCI's broad Asia-Pacific index was down 0.7%, while Japan's Nikkei tumbled more than 2%. weakness followed a tech-led slide on Wall Street overnight. Investors watching closely for September nonfarm payrolls report to gauge the strength of the US economy.

Article Title: Cooked! Under pressure from Trump, India to buy LPG from US citing demand fired up by Ujjwala
Article Text:
Representative AI image

TOI correspondent from Washington

India Brushes Off US Threats, Doubles Russian Oil Imports Amid Global Tensions | Watch

: In a landmark move to both bolster its energy security and mollify MAGA-infused Washington, India will buy 2.2 million tonnes of liquid petroleum gas (LPG) from the United States under an initial one-year contract.The agreement marks the first structured purchase of American gas for the Indian market, with global giants Chevron, Phillips 66, and TotalEnergies Trading SA expected to ferry the LPG to India in 48 very-large gas tankers. Effective from January 2026, with possible extensions, the state-run oil majors Indian Oil Corporation (IOCL), Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL), and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd (HPCL) will handle supplies at the Indian end.“A historic first! One of the largest and the world’s fastest growing LPG market opens up to the United States,” India’s minister for petroleum and natural gas announced on social media on Monday, even as US President Donald Trump threw his support behind lawmakers drafting a bill that would sanction countries purchasing Russian oil and gas to the tune of 500 per cent.The legislation still has some distance to go. US Senators Lindsey Graham and Richard Blumenthal, who first introduced the bill in April 2025, said in a joint statement on Sunday that “The ultimate hammer to bring about the end of this war will be tariffs against countries, like China, India and Brazil, that prop up Putin’s war machine by purchasing cheap Russian oil and gas.”India buys most of the gas it imports from the Gulf, mainly Qatar, UAE and Saudi Arabia, even as it is whittling down oil purchase from Russia to free itself from the punitive 25 per cent additional sanctions tariff related to this.The volume of U.S export represents only 10per cent of India's total annual LPG imports projected at around 22 MTPA to meet surging domestic demand as more Indians transition to the use of LPG. This effectively leaves room for more purchases subject to competitive pricing.Puri said the purchase is based on using Mount Belvieu – the premier US LPG pricing hub – as the benchmark. While exact figures remain confidential, analysts peg Mont Belvieu propane at roughly $650–$700 per metric tonne and butane at $550–$600 per tonne as of November 2025.For Indian consumers, this translates to subsidized 14.2-kg cylinders under the Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) staying affordable at Rs 500–Rs 550, thanks to government absorbing over Rs 40,000 crore in subsidies last year amid 60per cent global price spikes.“Our PSU oil companies have been providing LPG at the lowest global prices to all our mothers and sisters. Even as global prices soared by over 60per cent last year, Modi Ji ensured that our Ujjwala consumers continued to receive LPG cylinder at just Rs 500-550 whereas the actual cost of the cylinder was over Rs 1100,” Puri said.The LPG deal forms part of a nascent bilateral trade agreement (BTA), with five negotiation rounds completed and a first-phase closure imminent, as confirmed by Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal. "This isn't just about energy; it's about fair, equitable ties," Goyal stated last week at the Udyog Samagam 2025 forum. Trump recently noted the two nations are "pretty close" to a "fair trade deal," potentially easing tariffs in exchange for boosted US energy inflows.India's push for diversification stems from its heavy reliance on imports, which met over 67per cent of LPG needs in 2024—a sharp rise from 47per cent in 2015—driven by stagnant domestic production and redirection of refinery output to higher-margin petrochemicals. Total consumption hit 28.7 million tonnes last year, with monthly averages at 2.6 million tonnes in early 2025, fueled by PMUY's expansion to 10.3 crore beneficiaries and a total domestic customer base of 33 crores.Historically, India has leaned on Gulf partners for over 80per cent of its LPG imports. Qatar dominates with a 27per cent share (down from 32 percent in 2012–13), followed by the UAE at 26per cent and Saudi Arabia at 19per cent. These Gulf majors have been reliable, but volatility—exacerbated by Red Sea disruptions and OPEC+ cuts—prompted the US outreach, according to New Delhi.Months of talks, including site visits by IOCL, BPCL, and HPCL executives to American facilities, paved the way. "We've shielded households from shocks; now, we're securing supplies," Puri emphasized on X, crediting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's vision.
Article Summary: India will buy 2.2 million tonnes of liquid petroleum gas (LPG) from the United States under an initial one-year contract. The agreement marks the first structured purchase of American gas for the Indian market, with global giants Chevron, Phillips 66, and TotalEnergies Trading SA expected to ferry the LPG to India in 48 gas tankers.

Article Title: US markets today: Wall Street turns mixed; Nvidia earnings loom large; first official economic data in six weeks due
Article Text:
Wall Street kicked off the trading day with a blend of uncertainty, as market players anxiously awaited Nvidia's financial disclosures and key US economic metrics post-federal shutdown. Alphabet experienced a striking ascent on the news of Berkshire Hathaway’s investment.

Wall Street opened the week on a subdued note on Monday as investors braced for Nvidia’s much-watched earnings and the first US government economic data release in six weeks. Trading was mixed in early hours, with futures on the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping less than 0.1 per cent, while Nasdaq futures nudged up by a similar margin.Alphabet shares jumped more than 4 per cent after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed in a regulatory filing that it had taken a stake of more than $4 billion in the Google parent.Nvidia, which recently became the first firm to briefly cross a $5 trillion market capitalisation, will release quarterly results on Wednesday after market close. The stock has eased in recent weeks amid warnings that AI-linked valuations may have overheated.The earnings print is expected to be a key test. Analysts said companies often counter overvaluation worries by “delivering solid growth in profits”, raising the stakes for Nvidia’s summer quarter.A string of major US retailers — Home Depot, Target and Walmart — will also post results this week, offering clues to consumer strength in the absence of official economic indicators.The 43-day federal shutdown halted key releases, leaving the Federal Reserve and markets without fresh numbers on jobs, inflation and GDP since late summer.The Labor Department will publish September hiring and unemployment data on Thursday, marking the end of the data drought.European markets slipped at midday, with Germany’s DAX down 0.6 per cent, France’s CAC 40 off 0.5 per cent, and the UK’s FTSE 100 easing 0.2 per cent.Asia saw mixed moves. Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 edged down 0.1 per cent to 50,323.91 after Japan reported an annualised 1.8 per cent contraction in the July–September quarter. The dollar strengthened to 154.86 yen from 154.58 yen.Chinese markets declined, with Hong Kong’s Hang Seng dropping 0.7 per cent and the Shanghai Composite down 0.5 per cent.Analysts pointed to rising regional tensions after China reacted sharply to Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s comments suggesting Tokyo could respond militarily if Beijing moved against Taiwan.“China’s escalation against Japan over Prime Minister Takaichi’s Taiwan remarks has moved from a diplomatic irritant to a consequential macro input, with markets now forced to reprice Asia’s near-term risk curve,” said Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management.South Korea’s Kospi surged 1.9 per cent to 4,089.25 on strong buying in chip stocks following announcements of AI cooperation with Nvidia. SK Hynix gained 8.2 per cent and Samsung Electronics rose 3.5 per cent.Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 was flat at 8,636.40, Taiwan’s Taiex added 0.2 per cent and India’s Sensex advanced 0.5 per cent.In commodities, US benchmark crude rose 14 cents to $60.23 a barrel, while Brent crude added 13 cents to $64.52.
Article Summary: Futures on the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped less than 0.1 per cent. Alphabet shares jumped more than 4 per cent after Berkshire Hathaway disclosed in a regulatory filing that it had taken a stake of more than $4 billion in the Google parent.

Article Title: Aviation boost: Emirates places $38 bn order for 65 Boeing 777X jets; delivery to begin 2027
Article Text:
Ethiopian Airlines placed a firm order for 11 Boeing 737-8 MAX aircraft.

Air Côte d’Ivoire confirmed an order for four Embraer E175 jets.

Later, Air Senegal finalised an order for nine Boeing 787-8 MAX aircraft.

Dubai’s biennial Air Show opened on Monday with a headline announcement from hometown carrier Emirates, which placed a $38-billion order for 65 Boeing 777-9 aircraft, reinforcing its push to expand long-haul capacity amid record earnings and rising traffic through the city’s East-West hub, AP reported.The new order takes Emirates’ total commitment for the upcoming 777-9 to 270 aircraft, cementing its position as Boeing’s largest customer for the wide-body jet, even as the programme faces repeated delays. The agreement also includes GE Engines, bundled into the total deal value.Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum, chairman and chief executive of Emirates, described the purchase as a vote of confidence in the long-term partnership with Boeing and GE.“It’s a long-term commitment that supports hundreds of thousands of high-value factory jobs, and it reinforces our 40-year partnership with Boeing and GE,” he said. Emirates remains the world’s largest operator of the Boeing 777 fleet, all powered by GE engines.Sheikh Ahmed said he expected Emirates to remain the biggest 777 operator “for the years to come”, adding that airlines needed larger aircraft to keep pace with global travel growth.He said the carrier looked forward to receiving its first 777-9 from the second quarter of 2027, pointedly glancing at Boeing as he mentioned the date.Boeing Commercial Airplanes president and CEO Stephanie Pope did not specify an entry-into-service timeline but said the jet would “further support Emirates' mission to connect people and places around the globe like never before”.Officials took no questions from the media following the announcement.New deals and regional ordersBoeing also announced a series of additional orders at the event:Dubai Air Show opens amid booming travel, military interestThe 2025 edition of the Air Show comes as Dubai witnesses unprecedented passenger volumes. Emirates posted $5.2 billion in annual profit last fiscal, while Dubai International Airport continues to lead the world in international passenger traffic.Emirates ordered $52 billion worth of Boeing aircraft at last year’s show. Sister carrier FlyDubai, which operates 95 Boeing 737 variants, is also expected to eye more single-aisle jets as it expands beyond its first wide-body order of 30 Boeing 787-9 Dreamliners placed in 2023.Meanwhile, Dubai’s government has unveiled a $35-billion plan to expand Al Maktoum International Airport to five runways and 400 aircraft gates within a decade, creating enormous new fleet requirements for both carriers.The show is also set to showcase renewed interest in flying taxis, alongside strong military participation.Russia’s Rosoboronexport returned with a large pavilion despite Western sanctions. The state arms exporter displayed the Sukhoi Su-57 stealth fighter and the Pantsir-SMD-E air defence system, products gaining fresh attention amid Middle East security concerns.Underscoring ongoing ties, UAE President Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan began his tour at the Russian pavilion, viewing a video of a Russian drone strike and later inspecting the cockpit of the Su-57.US Air Force pilots from the 55th Fighter Squadron were also spotted examining the aircraft. When asked whether the F-16s could shoot it down, one pilot smiled and replied: “It looks cool.”
Article Summary: Emirates placed a $38-billion order for 65 Boeing 777-9 aircraft. The agreement also includes GE Engines, bundled into the total deal value. Emirates remains the world’s largest operator of the Boeing 777 fleet, all powered by GE engines.

Article Title: LNG geopolitics: Sanctions reshape gas flows as reduced Russian supply fuels new volatility; US emerges as dominant but risky supplier
Article Text:
AI image

Donald Trump Signals Harsh Sanctions On Russia’s Trading Partners With India On List For Oil Trade

A new analysis by the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies has cautioned that the worldwide effort to move away from Russian gas is creating fresh instability in the market, largely because of tighter supplies and shifting political alignments.The report says that cutting reliance on Moscow has pushed several countries to depend more heavily on the United States, describing the shift as an increased dependence on “an increasingly volatile ally in the US.”According to news agency ANI, sanctions on Russian energy have pushed global demand towards American LNG, placing the US in a position to dominate LNG supply growth. Its export capacity is expected to almost double by 2030, at a time when the global gas market is already facing upheaval.The study warns that although a new wave of LNG supplies may ease pressure later this decade, price swings are likely to worsen in the near term.Gas is increasingly being used to back up renewable power, and delays in new investments could trigger shortages. Such pressures, the report notes, could fuel political friction, especially if major producers accuse the EU of adding regulatory and pricing uncertainties.The institute also highlighted concerns over Washington’s push to expand markets for US LNG — a trend particularly strong under the Trump administration — saying this could politicise gas trade and undermine long-term buyer confidence.The long-term outlook for natural gas is already uncertain, with renewables challenging it in Europe and China, and coal remaining competitive in India and parts of Asia.Another risk flagged in the report is the United States’ influence over global energy flows through the dollar-clearing system, which enables it to impose unilateral or secondary sanctions.This power, the study says, increases the chance of disruptions and is encouraging countries like Russia, China, India and Iran to explore trade in local currencies.Globalised gas markets have further amplified these vulnerabilities. As per ANI, interconnected benchmarks now mean that a supply shock in one region can instantly raise prices elsewhere. After the Ukraine conflict, European and Asian gas prices effectively converged, turning Europe’s energy crisis into Asia’s.The volatility has raised concerns among major Asian buyers, including China and India, about whether LNG can be relied upon for power generation and industrial use in the long run.India on Monday announced that it signed a significant one-year agreement to source 2.2 million tonnes of LPG from the United States — around 10 per cent of its annual imports — as part of its wider strategy to diversify fuel supplies.The deal comes amid strained India–US ties following President Donald Trump’s decision to raise tariffs on India to 50 per cent.
Article Summary: New analysis by the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies has cautioned that the worldwide effort to move away from Russian gas is creating fresh instability in the market. The study warns that although a new wave of LNG supplies may ease pressure later this decade, price swings are likely to worsen in the near term.

Article Title: Pakistan economy in shambles! Dollar access tightened; cash purchases capped at $500 to check outflows
Article Text:
Representative image

IMF Applauds India’s Growth And Reforms, Bails Pakistan Again Out From Economic Burden

Pakistan’s central bank has introduced new restrictions to reduce the cash outflow of US dollars and protect the value of the Pakistan rupee.The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has instructed banks not to hand out cash dollars to anyone who does not hold a foreign currency (FCY) account, meaning customers without such accounts can no longer buy cash dollars from banks.According to new agency PTI, the SBP circular states that all foreign currency sale transactions meant for deposits will now be completed through bank-to-bank transfers.The circular said: “In order to promote cashless economy , it has been decided that, henceforth, all FCY sale transactions to resident citizens of Pakistan for the purpose of deposit into FCY account will be executed through account-to-account transfer.”This effectively ends cash payouts for dollar purchases intended for deposit.Banks will now transfer dollars directly into a purchaser’s FCY account, while exchange dealers can give only $500 in cash without verification.Any higher amount will require customers to present documents, state their purpose, and complete biometric verification. Even those travelling for Hajj, Umra or studying abroad will need full documentation to buy more than $500.Exchange companies must also follow stricter procedures.Sardar Naseem of Galaxy Exchange was quoted as saying by PTI that customers buying dollars for deposit will receive cheques instead of cash, which banks will then credit to FCY accounts.He said the move is aimed at controlling the outflow of dollars and preventing money changers from keeping large dollar reserves in bank accounts.Currency experts cautioned that buyers of euros or pounds may face delays, as cheques issued for these currencies could take five to seven days to clear.Pakistan’s financial pressures have been mounting, as the country’s total public debt climbed to $286.832 billion (PKR 80.6 trillion) by June 2025, nearly 13% higher than the previous year.According to the finance ministry’s Annual Debt Review, the debt-to-GDP ratio rose to about 70%, driven largely by weaker-than-expected economic growth and subdued inflation.Domestic debt jumped 15% year-on-year while external debt increased by 6% to $91.8 billion, supported by IMF disbursements, a $1 billion ADB-guaranteed commercial loan, and fresh inflows from multilateral lenders.Provincial debt also rose, led by Punjab and Sindh, while overall 84% of the country’s external public debt sits with the federal government.Despite some signs of recovery—such as a current account surplus, higher reserves of $16.64 billion, and modest GDP growth—the rising debt burden underlines Pakistan’s fragile economic position.
Article Summary: State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has instructed banks not to hand out cash dollars to anyone who does not hold a foreign currency (FCY) account. Customers without FCY accounts can no longer buy cash dollars from banks. SBP circular states that all foreign currency sale transactions meant for deposits will now be completed through bank-to-bank transfers.

Article Title: Global equity outlook: Goldman Sachs projects 7.7% decade returns; earnings, payouts fuel forecast
Article Text:
Representative image

Global equities are expected to generate strong long-term gains even though market valuations remain high, with Goldman Sachs forecasting an annualised return of 7.7 per cent in US Dollar terms over the next decade.The projection comes from the investment bank’s latest Global Strategy Paper titled Building Long-Term Returns: Our 10-Year Forecasts.According to news agency ANI, Goldman Sachs said its estimate is close to the historical median and is supported by structural factors such as nominal growth, profitability and shareholder payouts.The bank noted, “We expect global equities to deliver a 10-year total return of 7.7 per cent in USD,” despite pricey starting valuations.The firm’s building-block model derives long-term returns from earnings growth, dividend yield and valuation changes.Earnings remain the key driver, with Goldman Sachs expecting global earnings — including buybacks — to grow at roughly 6 per cent annually, ANI reported.Dividends are likely to contribute about 2 per cent, while valuations may slightly weigh on returns over the decade.Goldman Sachs acknowledged that current market valuations, at around 19 times forward earnings, are elevated but said “valuation, however, is not the whole story” and pointed to higher margins and improved return on equity as support for these levels.Regional returns over the next 10 years are expected to vary significantly. Emerging Markets are projected to deliver the highest returns at 10.9 per cent, driven by strong earnings growth in China and India.Asia ex-Japan may generate 10.3 per cent, supported by 9 per cent earnings growth and a 2.7 per cent dividend yield.Japan is forecast to give 8.2 per cent, helped by reforms and 6 per cent EPS growth. Europe may return 7.1 per cent, with about half coming from dividends and buybacks, as per ANI.The United States is expected to lag at 6.5 per cent due to expensive valuations and modest dividend payouts.While the report does not directly model the impact of artificial intelligence, Goldman Sachs said AI could offer further upside, with benefits likely to be broad-based rather than limited to US technology companies.The bank added that its baseline does not factor in “extreme shocks or blue-sky optimism”, though alternative scenarios range from 3.6 per cent to 10.5 per cent annualised returns.Despite uncertainties, Goldman Sachs said investors can anticipate favourable long-term outcomes: “We expect global equities to deliver solid long-term returns despite elevated valuations.”
Article Summary: The projection comes from the investment bank’s latest Global Strategy Paper titled Building Long-Term Returns: Our 10-Year Forecasts. Emerging Markets are projected to deliver the highest returns at 10.9 per cent, driven by strong earnings growth in China and India.

Article Title: 1.14 lakh startups generate more than 12 lakh jobs in India: Finance ministry

Finance Ministry

NEW DELHI: More than 1.14 lakh startups in India have created over 12 lakh jobs so far, the finance ministry said in its latest review of the Indian economy.In the report titled, ‘The Indian Economy: A Review January 2024’, the Department of Economic Affairs said that the 1.14 lakh startups recognised by the government under the 'Startup India initiative’ created more than 12 lakh jobs (as of October 2023).The state-owned e-commerce platform Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC) clocked more than 63 lakh transactions till November 2023, the document read.Despite facing global challenges in 2023 like valuation issues, few IPOs, regulatory changes and macroeconomic and geopolitical trends, India remains the third largest tech start-up ecosystem globally, with over 950 tech startups founded last year.The cumulative funding for more than 31,000 tech start ups has exceeded $70 billion (from 2019 to 2023), according to a recent report by Nasscom in collaboration with Zinnov.“In 2023, despite facing global economic and regulatory challenges, Indian tech startups have prioritised the imperative of enhancing their business fundamentals, driving profitability and growth,” said Debjani Ghosh, President, Nasscom.“The proliferation of tech startups in tier 2 and 3 cities marks the ecosystem's resilience,” she added.Navigating 2024, tech startup founders expect to continue the revenue growth path with measured steps focusing on optimising expenditure and maximising profitability for B2B tech startups.Investments in deeptech will continue an upward trend in 2024. With generative AI (GenAI) acceleration, 70 per cent of start-up founders are embedding artificial intelligence (AI) in their solutions.As funding becomes scarce for the Indian startup ecosystem in general, the explosion of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has given a new lease of life to entrepreneurs and founders in the country, as the Centre extends support to the sector.
